description.narrative: SITE Network of economic research on transition economis. There is a separate decision for Russian part.

SITE har ett mångårigt forskningssamarbete med systerorganisationer i regionen. Insatsen syftar till att tillgängliggöra resultaten för beslutsfattare och civila samhället. SITE vill därför - etablera en plattform för att kunna sprida befintlig kunskap - verka för bibehållen jämställdhet inom forskargruppen - öka forskningsutbyte och samverkan internationellt - ge administrativt stöd till institutionerna för en mer aktiv roll
Insatsen förväntas bidra till att beslutsfattare bättre kan formulera reformförslag utifrån sin egen verklighet och ha bättre möjlighet att förankara reformerna hos allmänheten. Reformerna är nödvändiga för utvecklingen mot marknadsekonomi. Kunskap och förankring är nödvändiga för ökad stabilitet och en förutsättning för ansvarsutkrävande.

The project "Extending the FREE network project: Forum for Research on Gender gaps Eastern Europe (FROGEE) 2014 - 2021" Contribution No. 55030237 is implemented within the FREE (Forum for Research on Eastern Europe and emerging economies) and is led by Stockholm institute of transitions economy. The initiative includes institutions in Russia (CEFIR and NES), Latvia (BICEPS and SSE Riga), Poland (CenEA), Belarus (BEROC), Ukraine (KSE), and Georgia (ISET). with the aim to build these institutions, the ambition has been to attract WesternThe overall objective of the project is to enable reforms that contribute to economic development and EU integration, by way of strengthening economics education, research and policy advice in all Eastern Partnership countries.
The project has 4 main objective areas: I) Increase impact of Policy Analysis, the FREE and FROGEE Policy Briefs, and other activities to support the reform process II) Women and men shall have the same possibility to conduct qualified research III) Enhance Research Exchange and Collaboration IV) Support Local Capacity Building
Sub-goals o the project is: - An established platform to be able to disseminate existing knowledge -Maintained gender equality within the research group - Increased research exchange and collaboration better functioning research institutions with increased administrative support

tag.narrative: 16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.

description.narrative: 1.1. Background - The FREE and FROGEE networks within the framework of the regional SITE project includes research institutions in 8 countries, 7 of which are geographically adjacent to each other, and which have common context and conditions for discussing and finding solutions to problems that are often similar between these countries: --- Sweden (SITE) --- Russia (CEFIR/NES) --- Belarus (BEROC) --- Ukraine (KSE) --- Armenia (American University of Armenia) --- Georgia (ISET) --- Latvia (BICEPS/SSE Riga) --- Poland (CenEA) 1.2. Objectives of the project - The overall objective of the project is to enable reforms that contribute to economic development and EU integration, by way of strengthening economics education, research and policy advice in all Eastern Partnership countries. - The project is implemented within the FREE («Forum for Research on Eastern Europe and emerging economies») and FROGEE («Forum for Research on Gender Economics») networks. The project comprises the following institutions: --- SITE – Sweden, CEFIR/NES – Russia, BEROC – Belarus, KSE - the Ukraine, ISET – Georgia, American University – Armenia, BICEPS/SSE Riga – Latvia, CenEA – Poland. - I. The following results achieved / activities implemented during 2019 have been presented: - Component 1: «Increase impact of Policy Analysis, the FREE and FROGEE Policy Briefs, and other activities to support the reform process» --- the major continuous type of output in the FREE network is the FREE policy brief series, the aim being to produce one brief per week, with a longer break over the summer, published in collaboration with all nodes on the web platform http://freepolicybriefs.org (the page now works well on various mobile platforms) --- published a total of 35 briefs in 2019 (up from 27 in 2018, and 25 in 2017; 8 of which on gender-related issues) --- web-page now contains around 300 briefs and papers (published since 2011) --- FROGEE policy briefs are published under separate heading (aimed at providing overviews on economic research, specifically related to gender equality issues) --- continued expansion on Twitter, Facebook, Linkedin, Slideshare, with increased numbers of impressions and followers across all of them --- organised 32 (of which 6 on gender; compared to 25 in 2018, of which 5 on gender) physical meetings with researchers, policy-makers other stakeholders in 2019, in the form of seminars, conferences, round-tables (on average, one every second week throughout the year) --- organised the main policy event of the year in 2019, the FREE Network conference «Policy lessons after 30 years of research on transition», organised with CenEA, with over 100 participants --- organised the policy conference «Development day 2019: the state of democracy in Eastern Europe» (in Stockholm) --- organised the SITE Academic Conference «The long shadow of transition: the political economics of long-run development in Eastern Europe» (in Stockholm) --- major external events in 2019: ------ EBRD conference on corruption and anti-corruption policies (in Kiev), a FREE network event organised together with the International Economic Association, Kiev School of Economics, and SITE ------ IX International Conference in Economics and Finance (in Minsk), organised with BEROC and FREE Network Economic Research Centre ------ these events illustrate one of the underlying long-term goals of engaging academics with connections to the region, who are making careers abroad, in activities that support the development of research and policy in the region --- organised a FROGEE event (in Tbilisi) on «Removing obstacles to gender equality and women’s economic empowerment», together with ISET --- organised a special session on gender economics at the Baltic Economic Forum and the Public Lectures on Gender Economics at NES (in Moscow) on i.a. women’s under-representation in politics, and economic impact of gender inequality --- seminars/conferences, organised by SITE and FREE network, continue to work as one of the central meeting-places for researchers and policy makers from the region (being venues for sharing ideas and developing both research and policy agenda in a way that is consistent with building modern, democratic, market-based economies; educating a new generation of policy-makers in the region that are already now occupying key positions in ministries, central banks and at regulatory agencies that are involved in implementing reforms; being a pool of ideas and competent individuals, that governments in the region can draw upon in ways that are difficult to predict, but, nevertheless, occurs continuously) --- in August 2019, FREE network member and president of Kiev School of Economics, Tymofiy Mylovanov, was appointed Minister of Economic Development, Trade and Agriculture of the Ukraine (several FREE network participants have, over the years, ended up in similar positions) --- at the conference «Policy lessons after 30 years of research on transition», one of its speakers, Leszek Balcerowicz, a key figure in the Polish transition (Deputy Prime Minister, Finance Minister, Chairman of the National Bank of Poland, etc.) picked up some arguments of relevance for the (at the time) up-coming Polish elections, (together with a WB publication, based on research by CenEA staff) during a TV debate, which brought media attention to the said report; this attention, in turn, led to a presentation of the report in Sweden, with attention from the Swedish-Polish Chamber of Commerce and the Polish Embassy, as well as a more general audience (it goes without saying, that the actual impact is difficult to measure and quantify, but it is likely that the said conference had an important impact) - Component 2: «Women and men shall have the same possibility to conduct qualified research» --- it is ensured that men and women, within the FREE network, are provided equal opportunities to conduct research and make their research know in policy briefs and at seminars and conferences (at SITE and FREE network men and women are employed in equal shares; at ISET the substantial majority of staff at all levels is female) --- 39 percent of policy brief authors were women - Component 3: «Enhance research exchange and collaboration» --- most FREE network events have defined research exchange dimensions (i.a. the annual FREE network conference is about getting researchers together and to present research and discuss possible collaboration) --- the FROGEE network has also worked as a platform for more and deeper collaboration within the network (the very structure of the FROGEE Policy Briefs enforces researchers from all nodes within the network to more actively inter-act with one another, than has usually been the case before) --- to help foster a new generation of researchers and policy-makers in the region, SITE continues to invite master students from different programmes across the FREE network to visit the Stockholm School of Economics (in Stockholm they meet with academic staff and various policy institutions, and, importantly, they also lay the foundations of future contacts across the countries, involved in the network) - Component 4: «Support local capacity-building» --- during the FREE network conference in Gdansk, the administration teams have separate capacity-building programmes, aimed at developing and exchanging ideas --- members of the SITE management team continue to play an active role in governing and advisory boards of the network institutes, participating in board meetings and various type of on-line consultations on a continuous basis throughout the year (most institutes being independent today, SITE still plays a key role in the network as hub coordinator of activities and collaboration promoter, both in terms of research and policy work) --- in 2019, the network increased cooperation and contacts with researchers at the American University in Armenia, which now participates in FROGEE activities - II. Factor, affecting project implementation: - One factor has mainly affected project implementation. As of March 2020, the Covid-19 situation has forced project management and participating institutions to take pro-active measures to mitigate the consequences, meaning that many physical activities have been replaced, to the extent possible, by virtual (Zoom on-line) activities, whereas some have been postponed for an undefined time or cancelled. Virtual activities have been mainly with local business entities, somewhat less with government authorities. Most official travel has been postponed until further notice. As in many other work-places, most faculty and staff work on-line from home and not at the office, as long as internet access remains at a reasonable level. Surveys are regularly being done on-line, regardless of virus. - To fill in the gaps of reliable information about the Corona situation participating FREE Network institutions regularly collect and compile data on the health situation in the region, and on what measures the authorities are taking in terms of mainly economic policies. These data are published on the FREE policy brief web-site and regularly up-dated in order to inform policy-makers, media, business entities and others in the region. - It is assessed that project management and participating institutions have done, whatever has been possible, in order to minimise consequences of the Corona situation. - III.Overall assessment of project progress: - (i) On the overall, project progress can be assessed to have been well on track, until the Corona situation started. (ii) Since network institutions are very dependant on one another in order to reach set-up project goals, and physical activities cannot fully be replaced by virtual ones, it is likely that implementation will be delayed. It is at this point, however, not possible to forecast the extent of this delay, since the Corona situation will continue until the beginning of 2021, at least, totalling the time, when restrictions have been in force, to one year or more. (iii) Judging from the project management’s and participating institutions’ pro-active mitigation measures, implemented since March 2020, it is assessed that consequences for the project will likely be minimised, to the extent possible.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

sida:strategy.sida:title: Reform cooperation with the Eastern Europe 2021-2027
